comments.content: Agreed. Without admin intervention would be D
True and D should be the correct answer!

choices.B: Increase the computing resources to the web server.
choices.D: Partner with a cloud provider to scale the required resources as needed.
choices.A: Install and deploy a load balancer in the front of the web server.
choices.C: Increase the network's bandwidth to handle the spike.

questions.question_text: A cloud-based web store is experiencing poor website performance and unavailability. Which of the following approaches would prevent the issue without administrator intervention?

A technician is configuring a new web application to be highly available. The technician has configured multiple web servers in different availability zones at a public cloud provider. The application requires users to be directed to the same server each time they visit. Which of the following network components is MOST likely to accomplish this?

discussion.content: Going with (C) on this. I think this is a duplicate question though

I believe B is the answer since A, C, and D are definitely not correct for SAAS. 
In the case of SAAS, B makes the most sense in comparison to the other answers regardless of the level of effort or practicality.

Wouldn't a firewall just be used to block the incoming web-based SaaS solution that you paid for already? I think IPSec is the correct answer to add encryption to your new web-based SaaS solution. Someone please tell me I'm wrong.

I think C is correct. This is because regardless of the cloud model (IaaS, PaaS, SaaS), the introduction of the firewall is the security responsibility of the CSP.

reference:
https://cloudsecurityalliance.org/blog/2019/09/05/how-to-share-the-security-responsibility-between-the-csp-and-customer/

comments.content: I would say C Firewall more specifically a WAF (web application firewall)

discussion.content: C for SaaS will work, NOT B because we cannot set this up for all users too labor intensive

questions.question_text: Which of the following would be appropriate when considering inbound access security for a web-based SaaS solution?

comments.content: totally agree!! - the answer is A !!

discussion.content: A is better addresses CPU at 90%, B only addresses storage capacity

Selected Answer: A
A will address the increasing cpu AND storage trend
The answer would be B. If you enable compression or deduplication this would increase the latency rather than lower it thus breaching SLA requirements further.

choices.C: Enable compression on the storage side.
choices.A: Add computing nodes and data nodes on the storage side.
choices.B: Add more storage shelves to the current array.
choices.D: Enable deduplication on the storage side.

discussion.content: I believe the answer is A - note that the question says "Below are the backups currently available for the VM". These are indeed available. The snapshot *is* available and would be the best solution for restore. The answer therefore is B.
the answer is B, you can not use a synthetic full back up to spin up a virtual machine it has to be a full backup (in reality a "synthetic full backup" is much like a incremental backup)
Must B, Full backup. VM was deleted, can not revert by snapshot.

choices.B: Full from three days ago at 00:00
